properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total accumulation of 5 cm along the central coast tonight. A low pressure system will bring snow mixed with rain beginning early this evening to the central coast. The mixed precipitation will change to rain by early Sunday morning as milder air comes in. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-24T04:53:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-23T12:54:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2926230140.2021
Area: Central Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total accumulation of 5 to 15 cm across B.C. south coast from tonight to Sunday afternoon. A cool airmass associated with a low pressure system will bring snow or rain beginning this evening on Vancouver Island and the Sunshine Coast and late this evening or midnight for the Lower Mainland and Malahat Highway. The mixed precipitation will change to snow by early Sunday morning as precipitation rates increase. The complex terrain around the south coast will result in varied snowfall totals across the region. Communities immediately near the water such as Comox, Parksville, Nanaimo and downtown Vancouver will see up to 5 cm of snow. Higher elevations and inland sections of Metro Vancouver, Fraser Valley - West, Vancouver Island and Sunshine Coast will see higher accumulations. At this time, elevations near 300 metres of Metro Vancouver could see up to 10 cm of snow. Inland and higher elevations of East Vancouver Island - Campbell River to Courtenay could see 10 to 15 cm. The Malahat Highway will see 10 cm of snow between tonight and Sunday afternoon. Snow will change to rain or become mixed with rain late Sunday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-24T04:53:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-23T12:54:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2062281862.2021
Area: East Vancouver Island - Duncan to Nanaimo, East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay, East Vancouver Island - Courtenay to Campbell River, Sunshine Coast - Gibsons to Earls Cove, Sunshine Coast - Saltery Bay to Powell River, Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - central including the City of Vancouver Burnaby and New Westminster, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge, Metro Vancouver - southeast including Surrey and Langley, Fraser Valley - west including Abbotsford
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Valemount due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter (PM2.5). This advisory remains in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at www.bcairquality.ca. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-01-24T04:00:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-01-23T12:01:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3321765629.2021
Area: Yellowhead
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow is expected tonight and Sunday morning on Vancouver Island and Metro Vancouver southwest including Richmond and Delta. A cool airmass and low pressure system will slide along coastal B.C. today. Snow is forecast to begin tonight and continue into Sunday. By Sunday afternoon snow will become mixed with rain in many areas. Potential snowfall accumulation varies from 2 to 4 cm for the Richmond and Delta areas. On Vancouver Island, snowfall amounts are forecast to range from near 2 cm on the coasts to 5 to 10 cm inland. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-24T05:11:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-23T13:12:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1851674863.2021
Area: North Vancouver Island, West Vancouver Island, Inland Vancouver Island, Metro Vancouver - central including the City of Vancouver Burnaby and New Westminster, Metro Vancouver - southwest including Richmond and Delta
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for Sunday morning through to Sunday evening. Snow, at times heavy due to lake enhancement off of Lake Superior will result in poor road conditions and reduced visibilities. Total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are expected by the time the snow ends early Sunday evening with locally up to 15 cm, particularly over higher terrain. Expect travel to be impacted along Highway 17 from Wawa to Nipigon. Snow covered roads and reduced visibilities in heavy bursts of snow will make travel difficult. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. Slow down and allow for extra time to reach your destination. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-24T12:48:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-23T20:49:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0775927579.2021
Area: Nipigon - Rossport, Marathon - Schreiber, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect today. A snow squall from Bayfield towards Dorchester is affecting the area and will meander through the region today. Some locales may receive up to 4 cm of snowfall before the snow tapers off this afternoon. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-24T06:45:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-23T15:13:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1117327154.2021
Area: London - Parkhill - Eastern Middlesex County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR QUESNEL (January 22, 2021 13:00 - Surrey) The Ministry of Environment & Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Quesnel due to high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes; respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at: https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-landwater/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-01-24T04:00:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-01-23T12:01:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1008449809.2021
Area: Cariboo - north including Quesnel
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard or near blizzard conditions are expected Sunday night and Monday. Strong east winds up to 70 km/h will develop Sunday afternoon reducing the visibility in blowing snow. Blowing snow will persist until Monday evening when the winds will begin to weaken. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values near minus 40 are expected overnight. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Locations: southeastern Labrador from Rigolet to Lodge Bay. Additional snowfall: 20 to 40 cm (tonight through Sunday night) in coastal communities; locally 40 to 70 cm inland and over higher terrain. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly up to 80 km/h at times. Remarks: Snow is expected to become heavy at times again tonight, and will persist through Sunday into Sunday night. Strong northeasterly winds will also spread across southeastern Labrador by Sunday causing poor visibilities in blowing snow. A general improving trend is expected to commence Monday or Tuesday. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Road closures are possible. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-24T11:37:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-23T19:38:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1114664291.2021
Area: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this afternoon and early this evening. Snow squalls will move into the region beginning this afternoon. Reduced visibilities in heavy bursts of snow and snow covered roads may make travel difficult, especially for areas closer to the shores of Lake Huron. Additional snowfall amounts of up to 5 cm is possible by this evening. Conditions should improve later this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. An arctic ridge of high pressure will help clear skies over central Saskatchewan, western Manitoba and Manitoba Interlake regions tonight and Sunday morning. Lows in the minus thirties along with winds of 10 to 15 km/h will produce extreme cold windchills of minus 40 or lower before dawn on Sunday. Temperatures are expected to moderate in the morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-24T13:31:38-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. An arctic ridge of high pressure will help clear skies over central Saskatchewan, western Manitoba and Manitoba Interlake regions tonight and Sunday morning. Lows in the minus thirties along with winds of 10 to 15 km/h will produce extreme cold windchills of minus 40 or lower before dawn on Sunday. Temperatures are expected to moderate in the morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Sant at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in blowing snow is expected or occurring. Locations: Postville - Makkovik. Expected snowfall: 10 to 15 cm (tonight through Sunday night), with higher amounts inland and over elevated terrain. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 70 km/h (tonight through Sunday). Remarks: Periods of freezing drizzle will give way to periods of snow and blowing snow tonight. Occasional snow and blowing snow will then persist through Sunday and Sunday night. Blizzard-like conditions may occur inland and over elevated terrain, where accumulations will likely be substantially higher. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-24T11:40:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-23T19:41:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3729847462.2021
Area: Postville - Makkovik
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls continue this afternoon and early this evening. Snow squalls extending from Amberley southeast to St. Mary's will move northward this afternoon, weakening with time and coming to an end this evening. Under the heaviest snow squall bands snowfall amounts up to 5 cm are possible by this evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-24T08:47:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-23T20:12:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1763399000.2021
Area: Wingham - Blyth - Northern Huron County, Listowel - Milverton - Northern Perth County, Goderich - Bluewater - Southern Huron County, Stratford - Mitchell - Southern Perth County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Locations: northern parts of the Northern Peninsula. Additional snowfall: 15 to 25 cm (tonight through Sunday night), with higher amounts possible inland. Maximum wind gusts: southwesterly 50 km/h tonight, then northwesterly 50 to 70 km/h Sunday. Remarks: Snow will ease this evening but will redevelop overnight and persist on Sunday. Strong winds coinciding with fresh snow will cause reduced visibility in blowing snow over exposed areas. Conditions are expected to begin improving Sunday night. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-24T11:08:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-23T19:09:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2667037288.2021
Area: Northern Peninsula East, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values near minus 45 or colder are expected overnight. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions are expected to develop on Sunday morning. Strong easterly winds, gusting near 70 km/h, will combine with falling snow to reduce visibilities. Blizzard conditions are expected to persist on Monday before easing on Monday evening. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values near minus 45 or colder are expected overnight into Sunday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Sant at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect this afternoon. A snow squall from Goderich to Woodstock is affecting the area and will meander through the region today. Up to 4 cm of snowfall is possible before the snow tapers off later this afternoon. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-24T01:10:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-23T19:16:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0659104058.2021
Area: Woodstock - Tillsonburg - Oxford County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. An arctic ridge of high pressure will help clear skies over central Saskatchewan, western Manitoba and Manitoba Interlake regions tonight and Sunday morning. Lows in the minus thirties along with winds of 10 to 15 km/h will produce extreme cold windchills of minus 40 or lower before dawn on Sunday. Temperatures are expected to moderate in the morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-24T13:31:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-23T21:32:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4178151333.2021
Area: Lake Winnipegosis, Lake Manitoba

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring. Locations: Trans-Labrador Highway from Kenamu River to Cartwright Junction. Additional snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 60 to 70 km/h. Time span: tonight through Sunday night. Remarks: Strong winds will combine with ongoing snowfall to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to begin improving as snowfall rates ease on Sunday night. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 centimetres combined with strong winds will give winter storm conditions over these regions beginning this evening until Sunday afternoon. The worst conditions are expected tonight as visibility will be greatly reduced in blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-24T13:00:38-00:00
